biblStruct.note: A passage within the Interpretatio epistulae ad Hebraeos, written by Theodoretus of Cyrus after 449, alludes to the anamnesis of the Antiochean “Anaphora of the Apostles.” Theodoretus appears to cite a passage of this anaphora that is also found within the Anaphora of St John Chrysostom, a Constantinopolitan derivative of the Antiochean anaphora. The anamnetic dimension attributed by Theodoret to the Christian cult, which excludes an offertory perspective, corrisponds to the prayer structure of the Syriac recension of the Antiochean anaphora, which, still today, is characterized by a “missing oblation”.
